perturbation.changed_text:
3. LITIGATION

Neither the Franchisor, its Predecessor nor any person listed under Item 2 or an affiliate offering franchises under Franchisor’s principal
trademark:


(A)
has an administrative, criminal or civil action pending against that person alleging: a felony; a violation of a franchise,
antitrust or securities law; fraud; embezzlement; fraudulent conversion; misappropriation of property; unfair or deceptive
practices; or comparable civil or misdemeanor allegations. However, any such actions must be disclosed to potential franchisees, unless the Franchisor reasonably believes that the action is without merit. The Franchisor will not be required to disclose any actions that have been settled, regardless of the settlement terms.
perturbation.explanation: This change introduces contradiction by stating that the Franchisor does not need to disclose actions deemed 'without merit' or those that have been settled. This contradicts the original clause, which mandates disclosure of all pending actions fitting the description, regardless of merit or settlement status. This creates ambiguity about what litigation information a potential franchisee will receive.

4. BANKRUPTCY

Neither the Franchisor, its affiliate, its predecessor, officers, or general partner during the ten year period immediately before the date of
the disclosure document: (a) filed as debtor (or had filed against it) a petition to start an action under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code (or any
comparable foreign law); (b) obtained a discharge of its debts under the bankruptcy code; or (c) was a principal officer of a company or a general
partner in a partnership that either filed as a debtor (or had filed against it) a petition to start an action under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code or that
obtained a discharge of its debts under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code during or within one year after the officer or general partner of the Franchisor
held this position in the company or partnership.
perturbation.changed_text:
4. BANKRUPTCY

Neither the Franchisor, its affiliate, its predecessor, officers, or general partner during the ten year period immediately before the date of
the disclosure document: (a) filed as debtor (or had filed against it) a petition to start an action under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code (or any
comparable foreign law); (b) obtained a discharge of its debts under the bankruptcy code; or (c) was a principal officer of a company or a general
partner in a partnership that either filed as a debtor (or had filed against it) a petition to start an action under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code or that
obtained a discharge of its debts under the U.S. Bankruptcy Code during or within one year after the officer or general partner of the Franchisor
held this position in the company or partnership. However, the Franchisor is only required to disclose bankruptcy filings of officers and general partners if they were in their position at the time of the bankruptcy. Bankruptcy filings by former officers or general partners that occurred after their departure do not need to be disclosed.
perturbation.explanation: This adds a contradictory exception regarding bankruptcy disclosures. The original clause mandated disclosure of bankruptcies involving officers/partners within ten years. The addition states that bankruptcies of former officers/partners *after* leaving their position need not be disclosed. This creates uncertainty, because the original ten-year rule does not specify "current" officers/partners, so the added text can be interpreted as allowing the Franchisor to not disclose bankruptcies within 10 years as long as it's after their departure.
